title: Translation Errors in VS Code Settings when 'French Language Pack for VS Code' is installed
body: - VS Code Version: 1.37.1 Date: 2019-08-15T16:16:34.800Z Electron: 4.2.7 Chrome: 69.0.3497.128 - OS Version: macOS Mojave 10.14.6 (18G95) Steps to Reproduce: (In order to see this issue, the 'French Language Pack for Visual Studio Code' must be installed.) - Open VS Code - Click on 'Code' (macOS version) => 'Preferences' => 'Settings' - The settings are now open in the right pane of the screen. - Go to 'Gestion de l'éditeur' under 'Banc d'essai' and you'll see this: In the block 'Reveal if Open': (second line) '...groupe éditeur actuellement active.' => must be 'actif' In the block 'Show Tabs' Contrôle si les ouverts éditeurs... => must be: Contrôle si les éditeurs ouverts ... If I knew where to find this in the VS Code repo but... If someone can tell me where to find this in it, it would be very nice and I would be able to correct it myself. That's it for now.

title: Quick open matcher weights
body: Issue Type: Bug It appears that the quick open matcher doesn't prioritize whole word matches at all. Here's me literally typing in an almost every word of a file's path in, only to find it on third place. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/161476/63953003-c9b1ad00-ca80-11e9-92cc-8c0d09bab809.png) Contrary to #56182, the files above haven't been opened recently VS Code version: Code 1.37.1 (f06011ac164ae4dc8e753a3fe7f9549844d15e35, 2019-08-15T16:16:34.800Z) OS version: Darwin x64 19.0.0

title: Debugger cannot resolve a "${file}" variable reference to a large file (250MB) passed as an argument
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.36.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Hello everybody,

I am currently trying to debug an application simulating large measurement files (250MB) passed as arguments.

My debugging configuration that I use for this is following:
```js
{
            "name": "Debug SIM -c -meas -b -s -1",
            "type": "cppdbg",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceFolder}/tools/sim/sim.exe",            
            "windows": {    
                "args": [
                    "-c", // continous mode
                    "-m", // measurement-based                           
                    "${file}",    // choose a measurement to be simulated 
                    "-b", // blind mode
                    "-s", // silent mode                                                                                   
                ]
            },            
            "stopAtEntry": true,            
            "cwd": "${workspaceFolder}",   
            "externalConsole": true,
            "MIMode": "gdb",
            "miDebuggerPath": "${workspaceFolder}/tools/mingw64/bin/gdb.exe",
            "setupCommands": [
                {
                    "description": "Enable pretty-printing for gdb",
                    "text": "-enable-pretty-printing",
                    "ignoreFailures": true
                }
            ]
        },
```

The steps I take and the feedback I get:
1. I click on one of the measurements that I have;
2. VS-Code tries to open it in the editor and reports: "The file is not displayed in the editor because it is too large (249.26MB)";
3. I press F5 to start a debugging session and pass the measurement file (as ${file}) to the debugger;
4. The VS-Code reports: "${file} can not be resolved. Please open an editor".

As I think, the reason is that the large measurement file is kind of not "completely" opened in the editor (I mean, opened and displayed), but only opened without being displayed, what seems to be a problem for the debugger or debugging adapter. 

It seems not to be able to reference a file, which is not opened and displayed.

At the same time, the following simulation tasks works perfectly (no problems with referencing):
```js
 {
            "label": "run SIM any_meas -i -m -v -b -s ",
            "type": "shell",
            "windows": {
                "command": "${workspaceFolder}//tools//sim//sim.exe",
                "args": [
                    "-i",
                    "-m",
                    "${file}",
                    "-v",
                    "-b",
                    "-s",
                ]
            },            
            "group": "none",
            "presentation": {
                "reveal": "always",
                "panel": "new"
            },
            "problemMatcher": []  // Never scan the task output
        },
```

The value of the "--max-memory" is much larger than 300MB and the latest Insiders-build has the same problem:(

Thank you in advance!!!

title: Scroll Issue in Top Menu
body:
If you enlarge the VSCode interface, then a scrollbar will appear in top menu items(View,Debug).

I found a problem with that scrollbar, if you try to scroll it to the end it scrolls back automatically in an abnormal way.

Have a look at the attached GIF for better understanding.

![vscodeScrollBug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43571677/63936329-fe216b00-ca78-11e9-8ad7-e8ffb07b157c.gif)


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enlarge interface by pressing Ctrl **+** + Button until a scrollbar appears in toolbar items(View, Debug).
2.  Select **View** from toolbar and try to scroll to the end. It will scroll backward after touching the end.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Support for the ppc64le architecture
body:
Currently there is a growing interesting in Power 9 machines like the libre Talos II workstation from Raptor Computing Systems.
On this front, Chromium and Electron have been ported to ppc64le. Those patches are slowly getting merged upstream, but unfortunately Google is taking quite some time to merge them.
Electron ppc64le: https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/15691
I would like to know how hard could it be to get VSCode working on ppc64le.

title: gray attributes in launch.json are confusing
body:
Related issues: #13353, #13979, #37459.
VSCode version: 1.37.1
OS Version: Windows 10 x64
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file called "launch.json" and populate it as described at https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/cpp/config-mingw#_configure-debug-settings
2. Observe that attributes "version", "configurations", "type", and "request" are rendered in a gray color.
3. Become confused about what this means.

Screenshot:

![gray-attributes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2909643/63901778-e683ad00-c9ba-11e9-9924-6cbdd9482486.png)

I understand from #13979 that this is considered intended behavior.  It is nevertheless confusing:

* The use of gray color to signify something is "less important" is unconventional.
* There is no way in the app to discover this novel convention.  Hovering does not show anything interesting.  Even the TextMate scope inspector shows nothing unusual.
* Elsewhere (both in VSCode and other applications), differently colored or styled attributes often indicate that something is an error, potentially leading the user on a wild goose chase to discover the problem (which is how I ended up here).

Hover:

![hover](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2909643/63902092-8130bb80-c9bc-11e9-987d-b73901bce538.png)

TextMate scope inspector:

![tm-inspector](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2909643/63902102-8f7ed780-c9bc-11e9-8e51-21f04c053033.png)

The impact of this confusion is magnified by the fact that every user who follows the [VSCode C++ configuration tutorial](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/cpp/config-mingw) will see it, and the screenshot in that tutorial does *not* show the gray attributes, further reinforcing the user's likely hypothesis that they have made a mistake.

This is what the tutorial looks like:

![should-look-like](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2909643/63902233-4f6c2480-c9bd-11e9-9522-af34661373e7.png)

I have read through the discussion in #13353.  My summary is that there was disagreement about whether these attributes even *are* "less important", and agreement that the use of gray color to signify that is likely to be confusing.  But, at least within the discussion there, these concerns were not resolved.

In my opinion, the gray color fails to ameliorate the problems #13353 was filed to address, and certainly leads to confusion, so ought to simply be removed.

As a tangential suggestion, the attribute hover text might be a good place to explain caveats regarding understanding or modifying those fields.

title: Find in selection: Don't expand a multiline find scope to line start/end (#80008)
body:
Re #80008.

## Previous behavior
When we had a multiline selection, it would automatically be expanded to the start of the first line / end of the last line before a "Find in selection" was attempted (same goes for a Replace).

This behavior may lead to confusion as to why results _outside_ the specified selection are found/replaced (imho, the use case presented in #80008 is entirely reasonable).

## New behavior
The selection is taken as-is, without expansion. Thus, only results inside the selection range are found/replaced.

## Notes
The previous behavior was introduced in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/1f0afd63edd445b74203a0bd445289e52fce04cf.
Maybe @rebornix can take a look and chime in as to why this change was made in the first place?
In my testing, I have not come across any issues with this change, but I may miss something here.

title: Regex-based replacing doesn't work properly when replacing in files.
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise 1903 x64 (OS Build 18362.295)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Make a directory with a file (or multiple files) containing text that matches the regex `^((\d{2}:?){2})\.(\d{3}) --> ((\d{2}:?){2})\.(\d{3})\n`
2. Open the directory with VSCode
3. Search for the aforementioned regex and try to replace with the string `00:$1,$3 --> 00:$4,$6\n`
4. Replaces will show the preview with `$x` instead of the replacement, and will show the same after replacing

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

Notes: 
- This exact find/replace works on single files.


### Example
File:
```
00:11.123 --> 00:14.245
Example
```
Result with `replace in files`:
```
00:$1,$3 --> 00:$4,$6
Example
```
Result with regular `replace` and same parameters:
```
00:00:11,123 --> 00:00:14,245
Example
```

NOT a duplicate of #21494

title: Non-WSL paths should be linkified in WSL terminals
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.37.1
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. start WSL in a VS Code terminal
2. echo "C:\\a\\b\\c.txt:14"
3. Ctrl+Mouse hover over text, and it won't be noticed by VS Code 

-- steps to reproduce are incorrect. The text probably needs to go through standard error.

AI initially started VS Code from the WSL command line. Option to reopen at startup look like "Abc [WSL] /c"

I did just see this working via Start/search bar/code. 

If you do the same from cmd.exe VS Code terminal window, VS Code will work as expected. Note: a path like /c/a/b/c.txt:14 will be recognised. The problem is that certain toolchains still know they're on windows, and will display errors with a back-slash+c: path style. It is nice to be able to work 100% in bash for consistency with target servers.

It's looking like only people using https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode-remote.remote-wsl will come across this issue.

... if you run cmd.exe from VS Code session initiated by WSL, and then fire off said toolchain, path patterns still fail to be recognised.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes, but WSL compatibility caused the issue. ie. (guessing again) VS Code starts stores config / session / temporary data using subsystem conventions (in this case Ubuntu). I like that. It's just that this assumption is incorrect in the case above (a toolchain runs on WSL but errs towards Windows path conventions on standard error, 'cause it knows).
